Award.AwardTitle: Functions of Carbon-Oxygen Hydrogen Bonding in Biological Methyl Transfer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program is funding Professor Raymond Trievel at the University of Michigan to investigate the proposition that methyl CH---O hydrogen bonding plays an important role in S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet or SAM)-dependent methyltransferases. Methyltransferases are enzymes that catalyze reactions in the metabolism of numerous biological molecules, as well as in cellular signaling through the methylation of proteins, DNA, and RNA. In addition, methyltransferases have been implicated in numerous diseases, making them attractive targets for the design of new drugs to treat cancer, cardio-vascular disease, microbial infections, and neurological disorders. Recent studies suggest that the transferred methyl group forms unconventional carbon-oxygen (CH---O) hydrogen bonds within the active sites of these enzymes. Although the existence of CH---O hydrogen bonds in biological macromolecules has been postulated for some time, the potential contributions of these interactions to biological processes, particularly methyl transfer, remain poorly defined. The goal of this project is to characterize the functions of these hydrogen bonds in methyltransferases using experimental and computational approaches. This project will engage both undergraduate and graduate students in the fields of biochemistry, structural biology, and spectroscopy, providing for a multi-disciplinary research experience at the chemistry-biology interface. It will also provide students with opportunities to perform sophisticated experiments at national research laboratories.

Using model methyltransferases, the functions of these hydrogen bonds in AdoMet recognition and methyl transfer catalysis will be examined using an integrated approach combining enzymology, crystallography, NMR spectroscopy, and computational methods. The results of these studies will be used to develop a conceptual framework that seeks to define the enzymatic roles of CH---O hydrogen bonding in AdoMet-dependent methyltransferases. In the broader context, it is envisioned that this work will yield insights that lead to a more general understanding of the contributions of these interactions to enzyme catalysis and biomolecular structure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Characterizing the Functions of Carbon-Oxygen Hydrogen Bonding in AdoMet-Dependent Methyltransferases

 

Robert J. Fick, Scott Horowitz, Mary C. Clay, Lucas L. Vander Lee, Brandon G. McDole, Ryan A. Mehl, Steve Scheiner, Hashim M. Al-Hashimi, Raymond C. Trievel

 

Methylation is a ubiquitous reaction in biology and is central to metabolism, cellular signaling transduction, and gene regulation. Most methyltransferases utilize the substrate S-adenosyl-L-methionine (AdoMet) and catalyze the transfer of its methyl group to different acceptor substrates. AdoMet-dependent methyltransferasesbelong to several structurally distinct classes which share a common reaction mechanism that arose through convergent evolution. However, the fundamental determinants underlying this shared methyl transfer mechanism remain undefined. A survey of high-resolution X-ray crystal structures in the Protein Data Bank reveals that unconventional carbon-oxygen hydrogen bonds coordinate the AdoMet methyl group in different methyltransferase classes which possess distinct active site structures and AdoMet binding conformations. This finding suggests that these intermolecular interactions may be important for AdoMet binding and the methyl transfer reaction.

To understand the functions of these carbon-oxygen hydrogen bonds, the bacterial enzyme TylM1 and the reactivation domain methionine synthase (MetH, the enzyme responsible for producing methionine) were chosen as model systems which represent two different classes of methyltransferases for structural and functional characterization. The active sites of these enzymes possess several residues that engage in either direct or water-mediated carbon-oxygen hydrogen bonds with AdoMet. Biochemical, biophysical, and computational studies of wild type TylM1 and MetH and active mutants which disrupt carbon-oxygen hydrogen bonding to the substrate demonstrate that these interactions are important for AdoMet binding and methyl transfer. These findings, in combination with prior studies of another model methyltransferase, human SET7/9, illustrate that carbon-oxygen hydrogen bonding between AdoMet and active site of methyltransferases represents a conserved feature among these enzymes that mediates substrate binding and catalysis. Knowledge of these interactions derived from our studies can be applied to the development of new methyltransferases inhibitors that can serve as novel drugs to treat cancer, neurodegenerative disorders, microbial infections, and other diseases linked to dysfunctions of these enzymes.
